title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: On each side of the picture of Nighean Ceard hangs a portrait, the three seeming to complete a historical group. One of them is described by the housekeeper of the Hunting  Lodge as that of " the Chief of Lochnaveen." It represents a very handsome young man, with the crisp golden locks, complexion like the opening apple-blossom, and the sapphire  eyes, bright as a falcon's at gaze, which bespeak the purest blood of Scandinavia, of those valiant Berserkers and renowned Sea-Kings who conquered, and so long held regal possession of the islands and peninsula of Scotland, after having been expelled from every other part of the British coasts.
